If you can, I ask you to find a way to give back. May we all do our part to ensure their sacrifices were not made in vain.

And we are charged with never forgetting the sacrifice of those who died for us to live.  This Memorial Day, I hope you'll join me in taking a moment to remember those who put their lives down for our country and vow to never take our freedoms for granted.

That means strengthening our VA system, providing for Gold Star families, and ensuring there are civilian opportunities for members of the military after their service. That also means making sure that our National Guard has the resources to fight this this global pandemic.

For their ultimate sacrifice, we are all charged with safeguarding and upholding the democracy that they lost their lives defending. We are charged with doing everything we can to support our military and military families in Congress.

Last week I read the words of President Truman inscribed in stone on the WWII memorial to my boys ‚ÄúOur debt to the heroic men and valiant women in the service of our country can never be repaid. They have earned our undying gratitude. America will never forget their sacrifices.‚Äù http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EY1jJjMXkAEIjRW.png

Today, let us commit ourselves to giving collective memory to the many patriots who have laid down their lives for liberty. We can never repay the debt we owe them, but instead we have to honor their memory with action.

I hope you take the time to remember the many brave men and women in uniform who gave the ultimate sacrifice over the last 242 years to protect the freedoms we treasure. God bless you and your family, and God bless America.

On this Memorial Day, while we can‚Äôt be together, we can still remember those who have given everything for this country. Listening to ‚ÄúTaps‚Äù connects us to them, and to each other, when we need it most.

It is the most emotional part of every service. Even now, when I participate in veterans events across the district, the playing of ‚ÄúTaps‚Äù is the hardest part to get through. And that goes doubly for Dave.

We‚Äôve mourned infantrymen from the 101st, which David served in, and so many others who took their own lives. And because ‚ÄúTaps‚Äù is played at every one of their memorials, the tune always brings back the cumulative loss we feel from all those that have died.

We've attended dozens of funerals and memorial services to mourn friends and colleagues like Stu, killed by a rocket in the Green Zone; Pat, Joe, Phil and Blaine, who were killed while preparing for deployment; Devon and Andy, who were killed on a peacekeeping mission in Kosovo.

I find that it's impossible to hear ‚ÄúTaps‚Äù without thinking of loss. When I joined the CIA and went to Iraq I started hearing ‚ÄúTaps‚Äù more often. When I met and married Dave, who had spent 30 years in the Army and served in Kosovo, the first Gulf War, and in Iraq, I heard it more.

This haunting tune started during the Civil War as a bugle call to signal end of day, replacing three taps of the drum that had signaled lights out. Soon after, it was played at its first military funeral because it was safer than the traditional firing of three rifle volleys.
Whether we would have gone to a parade, a cemetery, or a private ceremony, there is one thing that would surely be playing at every event this weekend: the playing of ‚ÄúTaps.‚Äù
Today, because of COVID-19, many of us who would otherwise be at Memorial Day events and services are home, doing our best to halt the virus.
